description: From Middle English ulage, from Anglo-Norman ulliage, from *ullier (“to fill a partially empty cask”), from Old French oel (“bunghole", literally, "eye”), from Latin oculus (“eye”). See French ouillage.

entries.meaning: In a wine bottle, the empty space between the cork and the top of the wine.
In a cask or barrel, the empty space, occupied by air, that is created by not completely filling the cask or barrel, or through spillage.
The topping-up of such a barrel with fresh wine.
In an industrial setting, the empty space in a tank, especially as for fuel.
Additional cargo of little or no value taken on to prevent movement of shifting of the purposive cargo.
examples: […]5 hhds. rum/ 5 bbls. flour/ 1 bbl. sugar/ 9 do. pork/ 1 do. suett/ 3 do. cocoa/ 6 do. peas/ 2 ullage bbls. vinegar[…]

verbs.description: ullage (third-person singular simple present ullages, present participle ullaging, simple past and past participle ullaged)

entries.meaning: To gauge the amount of empty space between the top of a cask and the level of liquid inside it.
